Note:
In London, British Library Addit. 31922 eleven lines in three stanzas; in London, British Library Addit. 28636 and London, British Library Egerton 2711, attributed to Wyatt and expanded to five quatrains and burden; see Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 85.
Subjects: complaints, lovers’; women, praise of; women, against
_description: Women kind and unkind — eleven to twenty lines in quatrains, with refrain, “A robin gentle Robin / tell me how thy leman doth / and thou shall know of mine.”

BLAdd17492.First Lines:
My ladye ys wnkynd pardyalas why is she sooshe lowes another
                    Better then Iand yett she wyll say noo…
BLAdd17492.Last Lines:
…at others fyers thy self to warnand lett them warn wyth
                    the
BLAdd17492.Note: Second occurrence in MS, four stanzas with refrain.

BLAdd31922.First Lines: A robyn gentyl robyn tel me how thy leman dothand thow shall know of myne…
BLAdd31922.Last Lines: …In faith my lady louith me wellShe will change for no new
